Closest and Most Interesting Meet of Season Goes to Lafayette by
The Johns Hopkins lacrosse

team added a fifth victory to its
list last Saturday by vanquishing
the University of Pennsylvania
twelve at Philadelphia. The game
belonged to the Baltimore lads
throughout except for the first few
minutes of play whin the Quakers
tallied two goals in rapid succession before the Black and Blue defense was able" to--settle down to
the serious part of the afternoon's
work. The game was played in a
sea of mud which slowed up the
action to a considerable extent and
took away some of the thrills ot
the sport.
Gardner, one of the Red and
Blue stickmen, started the scoring
soon after the opening of hostilities. This flashy player managed
to slip past Watson'just in time
to get a clean shot at the goal. Before the Hopkins team could get
collected their opponents had netted another point.
Hopkins Takes Lead

With the Philadelphians holding
a lead of two goals the Hopkins
stickwielders braced themselves to
the task placing the ball in the
net three -times before the end- of
the first half. From then on the
Black and Blue had little trouble
keeping the lead over their foes.
Despite the heavy mud the Marylanders were able to run clear of
the Pennsylvanians.
The second half (Sf- the contest
was even more to the favor of the
Blue Jays than the first. In this
period the Baltimore lads shot
four goals while Penn was limited
to a lone tally after the intermission.
Hopkins Has Better Team

Big pheasants, little pheasants,
fat pheasants, thin pheasants,
plain pheasants, beautiful pheasants, Ringnecked pheasants, Chinese pheasants, Mongolian pheasants, Golden pheasants—practically every branch of the species
so cherished by sportsmen was on
exhibition last Wednesday when
the Naturalists' Field Club,
through the courtesy of State
Game -Warden Le 'Compte, invaded the propagation farm near
Gwinnbrook. Cage. after cage of
gaily plumed birds greeted the
admiring gaze of some twentyfive biology enthusiasts who had
foresaken the microscope and the
research table to frolic in "the
great out of doors."

At the concluding fellowship
dinner of the year held in the
Friends' Meeting House last
Tuesday, Dr. Victor Mills, the
pastor of Grace Methodist Episcopal Church, of this city, discussed some of the problems of today.
The point which was stressed
most strongly during the talk was
that the solution of present and
future problems depends on the
younger generation. Dr. Mills
cited the World War as an instance which proves that the veneer of civilization is very thin.

Hatching Methods Interesting

Chickens are used to hatch the
pheasant eggs. Incubators, the
game warden implied, proved less
satisfactory than the employment
of the hen. The members of the
Field Club party were permitted
to inspect the hatching methods
as well as the assortment of eggs
to be shipped away. Every county of the state benefits equally
from this interesting estate.
Machines were provided for the
trip to Gwinnbrook. Five automobile loads made the trip; which
was the most interesting held this
year under the auspices of the local naturalists' organization. Dr.
Andrews, head of the Biology Department, and Dr. Cowles, Professor in Biology, were included
in the party.

The tactics of the Pennsylvania
twelve were somewhat different
than has been seen before but the
Black and Blue stickmen lost no
time in solving the plays which
were designed to baffle them. Several maneuvers resembled football
formations although conforming
to the rules of lacrosse in every
respect. These plays were ably
met by the Hopkins stickmen.
The Blue Jays played their
usual game, easily outshining the
heavy squad which opposed them.
Sanderson and Robinson on the
attack played well while Benedict, STUDENT ACTIVITIES COUNCIL HOLDS ELECTIONS

mainstays for the defense.

Lost and Found Bureau

Most of the students at the university seem to have forgotten
that there is a .lost and found bureau still in existence. Mr. Schaal
the "Y" secretary, announced that
articles have been accumulating
thru the year and some of them
are of real value. Some of the
things included in the list are
books of both the academic and
engineering schools, several fountain pens, Eversharp pencils and
otherwise, three bunches of keys,
a gray muffler and six or eight
pairs of gloves.

Americans are much addicted to
ancestral veneration—especial reverence is given to the forefather
type. This respect seems to have
been absent when a certain statue
was erected to George WashingLon. Now George probably is
slightly annoyed by the cherry
tree story, but this figure must
be downright irritating. There Ile
sits in the toga of a Roman senator. Well, you know what togas
are worth in cold- weather, .lear
reader, and the especial toga was
apparently made for a much
smaller senator than G. W. Anyhow, G. Washington exposes
enough of his epidermis to have
been fatal crossing the Delaware.
I magine the shock when George
from his Elysian perch descries
:he immodesty of his prototype.

Fifteen .non-fraternity .men and
seven fraternity ni-Zn were voted
into membership of the Campus
Club last Thursday. Excepting the

\V ith the government inspectors gone, the Hopkins R..0. T. C.
unit has passed the apex of its
year's schedule. The climax of a
year's training and a week's steady
drilling on the part of the unit was
reached last Wednesday and
"L'hursday, when Lieutenant Colo7
nel Walter, C. Short and Major
kobe-rt C. F. Goetz were sent by
the War Department to review
the Hopkins unit.
On Wednesday a quiz of the
freshmen in the unit was held for
the inspectors and in the afternoon the entire unit assembled on
the quadrangle for inspection and
pitching_ shelter tents. After the
unit had paraded before the inspectors with the band, the ranks
were opened and the men ordered
to pitch the tents and display their
equipment. The inspectors then
marched along the lines and questioned the men about their arms
and equipment. Close order drill
followed with the officers taking
turns as company commander.

was transacted.
The non-fraternity men are as
follows: Willing, Tatum, Wilcoxson, Fitzgerald, Marley, Grafflin,
Willoughby, Steinwald, King,
Tongue, Muir, Todd, Goodrich,
Ehle .and Lowman.
In order to keep the ratio of
non-fraternity men 2 to 1, the following seven fraternity men were
elected :- Gibson,--Morrel; Alckav,
Cleveland, Heyn, Brown and
Strathman. At present each fraternity on the Campus has one
representative in the Campus
Club.

The Johns Hopkins lacrosse

team added a fifth victory to its
list last Saturday by vanquishing
the University of Pennsylvania
twelve at Philadelphia. The game

throughout except for the first few

the serious part of the afternoon's
work. The game was played in a
sea of mud which slowed up the
action to a considerable extent and
took away some of the thrills ot
the sport.
Gardner, one of the Red and
Blue stickmen, started the scoring
soon after the opening of hostilities. This flashy player managed
to slip past Watson'just in time
to get a clean shot at the goal. Before the Hopkins team could get
collected their opponents had netted another point.
Hopkins Takes Lead

With the Philadelphians holding
a lead of two goals the Hopkins
stickwielders braced themselves to
the task placing the ball in the
net three -times before the end- of
the first half. From then on the
Black and Blue had little trouble
keeping the lead over their foes.
Despite the heavy mud the Marylanders were able to run clear of
the Pennsylvanians.
The second half (Sf- the contest
was even more to the favor of the
Blue Jays than the first. In this
period the Baltimore lads shot
four goals while Penn was limited
to a lone tally after the intermission.
